com.camerontec.util.datamodel.message

Class PooledMessageFactory<T extends Message>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.camerontec.util.datamodel.message.PooledMessageFactory<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - message type
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    CircularBufferConsumer<AtomicReference<T>>, PooledMessageFactoryMXBean, MessageFactory<T>

    public final class PooledMessageFactory<T extends Message>
extends Object
implements MessageFactory<T>, PooledMessageFactoryMXBean, CircularBufferConsumer<AtomicReference<T>>
    A message context which provides access to a set of pooled messages and associated pooled message resources.

    Each invocation of newMessage() attempts to check out a message from the pool, falling back to creating a new instance if the pool is exhausted.

    It is assumed that messages are checked back into the pool when they are recycled and each message checked out is provided with a context for doing this via PoolableSharedObject.setCheckedOutContext(com.camerontec.util.concurrent.pool.CheckedOutContext).

    Associated with each message are number of other resources:

    • fields
    • field groups
    • expression related resources

    These resources are also pooled, however, these pools are private to each message.

    Pool capacities and initial sizes may be controlled via MessageFactoryProperties.

    Pool capacities never change over time, however, when pooled resources are exhausted message factories fall back to object creation. Configuring small message pools is therefore possible at the cost of additional object creation and subsequent garbage collection.

    This class supports the concurrent acquisition and release of pooled messages. There is no practical limit to the number of threads involved. In order to support this a single internal thread is used to reclaim objects returned to the pool back into the free pools. It is therefore necessary to start instances of this class to activate the reclamation thread. Failure to do that will result in no objects being reclaimed and eventually garbage being created when the free pools are exhausted.

    Note: Once an instance of this class has been shutdown(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit) it may not be restarted.

    See Also:
    start(), shutdown(long, TimeUnit), MessageFactoryProperties, ReflectiveMessageFactory, PooledMessageContextResources

        Returns:

        Throws:

      • shutdown

        public boolean shutdown(long timeout,
                        TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Permanently shutdown the pool's reclamation thread.

        Following this the pool cannot be restarted.

        Parameters:
        timeout - The shutdown timeout.
        timeUnit - The shutdown time unit.
        Returns:
        True if the reclamation threads was shutdown, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If not started or previously shutdown.

      • onReadyToConsume

        public boolean onReadyToConsume(CircularBuffer.Entry<AtomicReference<T>> entry,
                                boolean isEndOfBatch)
        Description copied from interface: CircularBufferConsumer
        Callback used when a new entry is available for consumption.
        Specified by:
        onReadyToConsume in interface CircularBufferConsumer<AtomicReference<T extends Message>>
        Parameters:
        entry - The available entry to consume.
        isEndOfBatch - True if the available entry is the final entry in the current batch, false if their are more entries available (implying another entry will immediately be made available for consumption when this entry is consumed).
        Returns:
        If the consumer returns false then no further messages in this batch are delivered even when there are more to deliver, otherwise if the consumer returns true delivery continues until the end of the batch.
